hanzi-su-wiki:
貯

Значения

Копить, запасать, откладывать; откладывать; собирать коллекцию; оставлять несделанным

Мнемоника

Солдат 丁 — охранник у склада 宀 с ценностями 貝.

Варианты

贮
purpleculture_pinyin:
zhù
to store; to save; stockpile; Taiwan pr. [zhu3]
хранить; сохранить; склад; Тайвань пр. [zhu3]
rtega_mnemonic:
貯貯RS
贮贮		store, stockpile, hoard, savings
  • storing money 貝 in a quiet 宁 place
purpleculture_info:
(Simplified: 贮)
Pictophonetic: 宁 indicates the sound; 貝 (money) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
貯存 [ zhù cún ]: to store; to deposit
貯藏 [ zhù cáng ]: to store up; to hoard; deposits
貯備 [ zhù bèi ]: to store
貯木場 [ zhù mù chǎng ]: lumber yard
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿰ Left to right
    • 貝 [ bèi ] sea shell; money, currency
    • 宁 [ níng ] calm, peaceful; healthy; rather; to prefer
heisig_chinese_memo: It takes a lot more than to store up one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.
heisig_constituent: savings, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight, house, street, nail, spike
heisig_story: To avoid confusing this frame with the last one, try to think of savings as actual money. The only difference is that our currency is not paper bills but shells, a not uncommon unit of exchange in older civilizations. The nail under the roof of the house points to a hiding place in the rafters on which one strings up one's shells for safekeeping.
myStory: деньги в банке, видное место, вся улица твоя
Keyword_KANJIDIC: savings, store, lay in, keep, wear mustache
Keyword_KANJIDIC_ru: сбережения, магазин, лежали в, Кипы, износ усы
koohiiStory1: It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.
koohiiStory2: My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I´m very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.
jp_example_words:
貯蓄(ちょちく): savings
貯金(ちょきん): (bank) savings
貯蔵(ちょぞう): storage, preservation
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You keep all of your shellfish under a roof down the street and it's your savings. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine walking down the street to deposit more shellfish into your special savings and gaze happily at the huge pile you keep far enough away that you aren't tempted to spend it.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine trying to lift up a shellfish with a pair of smooth chopsticks. It slips right out. Ugh! I guess that's good though, because it's a savings for a reason (you shouldn't be spending it)!
Ru_Meaning: savings, store, lay in, keep, wear mustache
Ru_Radicals: 一 (один), 亅 (зазубрина), ハ, 宀 (значок У), 目 (глаз), 貝 (раковина)
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the calm (宁) shellfish (貝) has savings
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: In this house, the father likes to store up his savings under the floor.
humanum_short_description_en:
There is an old interpretation of Jinwen from " bei " from " ning ", and Li Xueqin interpreted as " jia ", see " Jia ".

"Shuowen": "Storage, accumulation, from Bei, Ningsheng."

"Said Wen." "Ning Bu": "Ning, distinguish the accumulation."
humanum_short_description:
金文有一舊釋為從「貝」從「宁」，李學勤釋為「賈」，參見「賈」。

　　《說文》：「貯，積也，從貝，宁聲。」

　　《說文﹒宁部》：「宁，辨積物也。」

貯字的基本解释

貯
zhù
见“贮”。

貯字的汉语字典释义

[①]［zhù］
［《廣韻》丁吕切，上語，知。］
“贮1”的繁体字。
(1)储存；收藏。
(2)指储存的财货。
(3)盛，把东西放在器具里。
(4)停放，安置。
(5)唐时图籍副本之一。
(6)通“佇”。等待。

貯字的康熙字典解释

【酉集中】【貝字部】　貯； 康熙笔画：12； 页码：页1206第09
【廣韻】丁呂切【集韻】展呂切，?音䘢。【說文】積也。【玉篇】藏也。【廣韻】居也。【公羊傳·僖三年】無貯粟。【前漢·食貨志】夫積貯者，天下之大命也。　又與?、褚同。【周禮·地官·廛人註】謂貨物?藏於市中。【釋文】?本或作貯，又作褚，皆同。　又同著。【史記·貨殖傳】積著之理。【註】著，張呂反。?字原从宁从著作。

貯字的源字形

字源演变：

甲骨文金文小篆楷体

暂无。

Name meaning

zhù
вм. 贮
Radicals: 貝, 宀, 丁  (shellfish, roof, street)
Meaning Mnemonic
You keep all of your shellfish under a roof down the street and it's your savings. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
Imagine walking down the street to deposit more shellfish into your special savings and gaze happily at the huge pile you keep far enough away that you aren't tempted to spend it.
Reading Mnemonic
When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.
Imagine trying to lift up a shellfish with a pair of smooth chopsticks. It slips right out. Ugh! I guess that's good though, because it's a savings for a reason (you shouldn't be spending it)!
